comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: On this page a mr. JayGee (short for John Grant I think) took some recent images with geotags of the Gobbins pathway, including this bridge, or what is left of it: www.johngrant.eu/sea-kayaking/gobbins1009 He was travelling in a kayak.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Well, I think I've found it on the OSNI site but I don't see a way to post a usable link. It's on the 1902 map at Sandy Cave near Burnside Cottages.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: The Gobbins, as noted on the photograph, are on Islandmagee, Co. Antrim. There is a scheme to reinstate the path and build a visitor's centre. Just waiting for funding. It's only a half hour's drive from home.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: It's difficult to match the map to google, since there doesn't seem to be any matching features between the two in this area, but I think this is it. maps.google.ie/maps?q=heddles+port&hl=en&ll=54.80...

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berkeley_Deane_Wise_at_the_Gob... this article says it was opened in 1902 and closed in 1961 due to coastal erosion. Couldnt have gone across it at anytime (shudder)

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Kind of apt for me as I was under these cliffs a fortnight ago. www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009/7596266668/in/photostream I took more images of the various sets of steps cut into the rocks and even where the path goes through a rock. Not sure how to link this to a map except the Flickr map And work is due to start this October on re-instating the path. www.larnetimes.co.uk/news/business/silence-is-golden-rule...

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Best I can do is a lat & long which you can use.  54 48. 03 N and 5 41. 23W. on Google Earth. That is the starting point of the path which then runs north along the cliffs and caves.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] That is just about correct - just the next wee lump of rock south. I did scramble along it in the early 1970s with a group of ramblers.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] Sad to see it so fallen into disrepair, although amazing perspective from the sea on a kayak! Also, our photo must have been taken after 1902, if that's when the cliff path was set up...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Not to worry about the OSNI link. Delighted with Sandy Cave and Burnside Cottages for our tags. They sound gorgeous.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mogey] Here is another photo of the terror bridge. www.flickr.com/photos/rbstewart/3162966661/ Here is a photo on Geograph www.geograph.ie/photo/849898 The couple sitting in the Wikipedia photo are the designer Berkeley Deane Wise and his wife. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berkeley_Deane_Wise "The 2 mile path was cut precipitously into the cliffs, with tunnels and bridges, including two tubular bridges 70 feet long that connected the 'Man o' War Stack' to the main path. The bridges were built in Belfast and floated to Islandmagee in barges to be lifted into position."

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Have renamed this photo in your honour!

The Wikepedia article says: "... After Wise left the company this final extension was opened in 1908, with a spectacular suspension bridge spanning the mouths of the Seven Sisters..."  Our tubular/terror bridge is the "spectacular bridge"? i.e. this photo taken after 1908?

Wonder if Berkeley Deane Wise is any relation of the Deanes who designed Library Towers?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03]  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/14302637@N08]  This is fascinating, what a bridge and what an area?  I never knew it existed and I imagine that crossing that bridge even on a very calm day was some experience.  Fantastic.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Speaking of Antrim and death defying, you should put up a picture of the Carrick A Rede rope bridge from before it was modernised. It was just two planks laid across about a dozen battens, the battens about six feet apart from each other and with nothing particularly to stop you falling to your death. After I had crossed it while a large gentleman of foreign extraction swung the bridge too and fro in a good natured effort to dislodge me, several people on the Island refused to return to the mainland.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: "The fine Cretaceous sections near Port Muck are not far from the third section of the path, which will cross the mouths of six of the "Seven Sisters" caves by a suspension bridge 250 feet long, and will have to be tunnelled inwards along a dangerous part of the cliff." dds.crl.edu/loadStream.asp?iid=15800 File Format: PDF/Adobe Acrobat Here are the "Seven Sisters" caves on Geograph, about 1km north of the Tubular Terror Bridges. www.geograph.ie/photo/2666723 The 1902 suspension bridges are much smaller but still bouncy. www.bridgemeister.com/pic.php?pid=911 How nonchalant the ladies look. The sea is quite handy for having a "Technicolor Yawn".
